<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

	<title>Chinese PlugX Malware Hidden in Your USB Devices?</title>
	<meta name="description" content="PlugX remains an active threat. A newly discovered variant infects USB devices and a similar variant makes copies of PDF and Microsoft Word files." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/plugx-variants-in-usbs/" />

	<meta property="og:description" content="PlugX remains an active threat. A newly discovered variant infects USB devices and a similar variant makes copies of PDF and Microsoft Word files." />
	<meta property="og:url" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/plugx-variants-in-usbs/" />

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Mike Harbison"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Jen Miller-Osborn"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/mike-harbison/"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/jen-miller-osborn/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="Black Basta ransomware,brute ratel c4,Dark Scorpius,GootLoader"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Malware-r3d1.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Chinese PlugX Malware Hidden in Your USB Devices?","name":"Chinese PlugX Malware Hidden in Your USB Devices?","description":"PlugX remains an active threat. A newly discovered variant infects USB devices and a similar variant makes copies of PDF and Microsoft Word files.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/plugx-variants-in-usbs\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/plugx-variants-in-usbs\/","datePublished":"January 26, 2023","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nRecently, our Unit 42 incident response team was engaged in a Black Basta breach response that uncovered several tools and malware samples on the victim's machines, including GootLoader malware, Brute Ratel C4 red-teaming tool and an older PlugX malware sample. The PlugX malware stood out to us as this variant infects any attached removable USB media devices such as floppy, thumb or flash drives and any additional systems the USB is later plugged into.\r\n\r\nThis PlugX malware also hides actor files in a USB device using a novel technique that works even on the most recent Windows operating systems (OS) at the time of writing this post. This means the malicious files can only be viewed on a Unix-like (*nix) OS or by mounting the USB device in a forensic tool.\r\n\r\nWe also discovered a similar variant of PlugX in VirusTotal that infects USB devices and copies all Adobe PDF and Microsoft Word files from the host. It places these copies in a hidden folder on the USB device that is created by the malware.\r\n\r\nPlugX is a second-stage implant used not only by multiple groups with a Chinese nexus but also by several cybercrime groups. It has been around for over a decade and has been observed in some high-profile cyberattacks, including the U.S. Government Office of Personnel Management (OPM) breach in 2015. It is a modular malware framework, supporting an evolving set of capabilities throughout the years.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive protections against the types of threats discussed in this blog by products including Cortex XDR and WildFire.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nPlugX, Brute Ratel C4\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIntroduction\r\nIt's not uncommon for multiple malware samples to be discovered during an investigation, as occurred in this situation with GootLoader, Brute Ratel C4 and PlugX. Numerous threat actors compromise targets and can coexist simultaneously on the affected machine.\r\n\r\nBecause we can\u2019t conclusively say whether these malware samples were left by one group or several, we can't attribute these tools to the Black Basta ransomware group. However, the version of Brute Ratel C4 used in this case is the same one reported by Trend Micro, which also involved the Black Basta ransomware group.\r\nPlugX Malware Infection\r\nHistorically, a PlugX infection begins by hijacking a known and trusted, digitally signed software application to load an actor-created encrypted payload. This technique has been used since 2010 and is listed in the MITRE ATT&amp;CK techniques as Hijack execution flow DLL-Side loading ID: T1574.002 Sub-technique T1574.\r\n\r\nIn this case, the threat actors decided to hijack a popular and free open source debugging tool for Windows called x64dbg, which is used by the malware analysis\/reverse engineering community. X64dbg applications are digitally signed by \"Open Source Developer Duncan Ogilvie.\"\r\n\r\nThe developers of this tool offer two types of debugger applications: x64 for 64-bit applications and x32 for 32-bit applications. In this case, the actors used x32dbg.exe, which is the 32-bit debugger of x64dbg.\r\n\r\nUpon execution of x32dbg.exe, Microsoft Windows will attempt to resolve any dependency files necessary to run the application. That search starts locally (i.e., in the current working directory). If found, the necessary files are loaded and executed.\r\n\r\nX32bridge.dll is a Windows Dynamic Link Library (DLL) dependency file of x32dbg.exe. A legitimate x32bridge.dll also carries the same digital signature. In this case, the file is not signed.\r\n\r\nOnce loaded, the malware searches locally for an actor-created encrypted payload file: x32bridge.dat (SHA256: e72e49dc1d95efabc2c12c46df373173f2e20dab715caf58b1be9ca41ec0e172).\r\n\r\nX32bridge.dat was first submitted to VirusTotal on Jan. 22, 2021. As of Dec. 15, 2022, it has a detection score of eight out of 61 engines. None of the engines identify the file as PlugX malware.\r\n\r\nOnce loaded and decrypted in memory, the malware infects the host and any removable USB devices attached with the PlugX malware. Figure 1 below illustrates PlugX DLL side loading using x64dbg DLL hijacking.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126790\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. PlugX DLL sideloading using x64dbg.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nBoth the hijacking of x64dbg and the association of this behavior with the PlugX malware were reported by Sophos back in November 2020. Their blog refers to this malware as KilllSomeOne, based on a Program Database (PDB) string found in one of the binaries.\r\n\r\nSophos performed an excellent analysis of the samples and touched on the USB infection. We confirmed that our sample matched the behaviors described in their report. From there, we wanted to expand our research by focusing on the USB infection, other USB variants in the wild and links to the PlugX malware.\r\nPlugX Malware USB Overview\r\nThe technique used by the PlugX malware to hide files in a USB device involves using a certain Unicode character. This hinders Windows Explorer and the command shell (cmd.exe) from displaying the USB directory structure and any files, concealing them from the victim.\r\n\r\nThe Unicode character used by this PlugX malware for the directories is 00A0 (a whitespace character called a no-break space). The whitespace character prevents the Windows Operating System from rendering the directory name, concealing it rather than leaving a nameless folder in Explorer.\r\n\r\nTo achieve code execution of the malware from the hidden directory, a Windows shortcut (.lnk) file is created on the root folder of the USB device. The shortcut path to the malware contains the Unicode whitespace character, which is a space that does not cause a line break, but this is not visible when viewed via Windows Explorer, as shown below in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126792\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"678\"] Figure 2. Windows shortcut properties for accessing the hidden directory.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWhen the shortcut file is viewed in a hex editor, the hex representation of these characters is shown as highlighted below in Figure 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126794\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. Windows shortcut properties shown in a hex editor display.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe PlugX malware uses the Component Object Model (COM) interface to create the .lnk files and includes the Unicode character 00A0. It does this by creating an instance of a shell desktop to create the associated Windows shortcut files. The ShellLink SetArguments method is used to set the command line arguments, which include the white space no break Unicode character, as shown in Figure 4 below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126796\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 4. COM ShellLink::SetArguments.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFinally, the ShellLink::Save method saves the shortcut file with all the changes.\r\nPlugX Malware USB Infection\r\nThe PlugX malware x32bridge.dll loads x32bridge.dat, which is responsible for implanting the host with malware and infecting any attached removable media USB devices such as floppy, thumb or flash drives. If a removable media device is found, the following steps are performed:\r\n\r\n \tIt creates the following directory structure:\r\n&lt;usb volume&gt;:\\u00A0\\u00A0\\RECYCLER.BIN\\files. Example: F:\\ \\ \\RECYCLER.BIN\\files.\r\n \tIt creates a hidden file named desktop.ini in each folder, which specifies the icon for the folder. This file contains the following data:\r\n\r\n[.ShellClassInfo]\r\nIconResource=%systemroot%\\system32\\SHELL32.dll,7\r\n\r\nThe Windows OS uses a single file to retrieve icon images that are displayed on the desktop as shortcuts or from Windows Explorer files and folders. The Shell32.dll file contains a list of icons and a unique number. In this case, the drive icon and the number 7 are used, as shown below in Figure 5.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126798\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"150\"] Figure 5. Drive icon number 7.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe use of this drive icon makes the directories appear as drives within Windows Explorer when viewed with hidden files enabled. If deleted, the directories appear as folders.\r\n\r\n \tIn the second directory, it creates a subfolder named RECYLER.BIN. This directory acts as a recycle bin. In that directory is a subdirectory named files and a hidden desktop.ini file. This desktop.ini file contains the following data:\r\n\r\n[.ShellClassInfo]\r\n\r\nCLSID = {645FF040-5081-101B-9F08-00AA002F954E}\r\n\r\nThis CLSID instructs Windows Explorer to display the created RECYCLER.BIN folder as a recycle bin directory by giving it the recycle bin icon. This is shown in Figure 11 as an example.\r\n\r\n \tThe files subfolder contains copies of the PlugX malware x32dbg.exe, any encrypted actor .dat files and the actor\u2019s malicious DLL. An example of this is shown in Figure 6 below.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126800\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. Infected UBS removable device displayed via WinHex.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIt should be noted that pre-infection of the USB device, existing files or directories on the root of the removable device are moved to the second hidden folder on the USB device, as shown below in Figure 7.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126802\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. Side-by-side comparison of the root directories of a non-infected versus infected USB device.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n \tWhenever the shortcut file from the infected USB device is clicked, the PlugX malware launches Windows Explorer and passes the directory path as a parameter. This then displays the files on the USB device from within the hidden directories and also infects the host with the PlugX malware. The victim sees their files and assumes all is working as expected.\r\n\r\nFigure 8 below illustrates how an infected USB thumb drive would appear to a victim in Windows Explorer using default settings (i.e., not displaying hidden files).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126804\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device. (Show hidden files not enabled.)[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAn infected PlugX USB device has no files or directories in the root folder and contains only a .lnk file.\r\n\r\nFigure 9 shows that the shortcut file is TESTDRIVE, which matches the USB device name. The shortcut file is responsible for infecting the host and navigating to the hidden directory on the USB device each time it is clicked. For example, the shortcut file referenced in Figure 9 contains the following data:\r\n\r\n%comspec% \/q \/c \" \\ \\RECYCLER.BIN\\files\\x32dbg.exe\"\r\n\r\nOnce the target clicks the shortcut, x32dbg.exe is launched via cmd.exe from the hidden files directory on the USB device. The host the USB is attached to is now infected with the PlugX malware.\r\n\r\nWhen viewing the contents of the infected USB device with Windows Explorer and hidden items enabled, a victim would see the following images:\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126806\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 9. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device (root folder).[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThey would then see the following, as shown in Figure 10, within the first hidden directory:\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126808\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 10. Windows Explorer showing an infected USB removable device (hidden directory number one).[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAs shown in Figure 11, Windows Explorer displays another hidden directory along with a shortcut file. The shortcut file has the same properties to launch x32dbg.exe and will infect the host with the USB device attached.\r\n\r\nWhen viewing the contents of the next hidden folder, Windows Explorer shows the following directory structure:\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126810\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 11. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device (hidden directory number two).[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis directory contains a RECYLER.BIN folder that masquerades as a Windows recycle bin, along with any files or directories that existed in the root folder of the USB device at the time of infection. When viewing the contents of the RECYLER.BIN with Windows Explorer, a victim will see what\u2019s shown in Figure 12:\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126812\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 12. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device (RECYLER.BIN folder).[\/caption]\r\n\r\nSince the default setting for Windows Explorer is not to show hidden items, the only item visible to the victim is the shortcut file, as shown in Figure 8. Even with hidden files enabled, Windows Explorer or cmd.exe cannot show the malware files that reside in the files subdirectory.\r\n\r\nThe malware files can only be viewed on a *nix OS or by mounting the USB device in a forensic tool. Figure 13 shows how the USB device looks once it\u2019s mounted in Ubuntu, browsing to it via File Explorer.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126814\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"549\"] Figure 13. Ubuntu File Explorer viewing an infected USB device.[\/caption]\r\nPlugX Malware Post USB Infection\r\nWhen a host is infected with this variant of the PlugX malware, the malware continuously monitors for USB removable devices. Once a USB device is discovered and infected, any new files written to the USB device root folder post-infection are moved to the hidden folder within the USB device. Since the Windows shortcut file resembles that of a USB device and the malware displays the victim's files, they unwittingly continue to spread the PlugX malware.\r\nPlugX Malware USB Variant Two\r\nArmed with this knowledge, we wondered if other similar PlugX USB infection malware existed in the wild. File SHA256: 5b496972a86cea66aeecaac6e3f67a92e22f35cd5d2a98d54a2f1218fcd5dfc5 in VirusTotal matches the behaviors of x32bridge.dat, specifically the creation of the Windows Scheduled Task and PDB string referenced in the Sophos blog.\r\n\r\nThis file is a Windows x86 PE file (DLL), the in-memory equivalent of x32bridge.dat. Our analysis shows the runtime behavior is identical to the x32bridge.dat USB infection detailed earlier, but it has an added capability. It copies documents from the host machine to a new hidden USB subfolder named da520e5.\r\n\r\nThe malware specifically copies all Adobe PDF and Microsoft Word documents from the host to this directory. Figure 14 below shows an example of the directory and files copied from our host.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_126816\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 14. PlugX malware variant with two exfil files.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis PlugX USB malware variant was designed to exfiltrate specific files from its target that could be retrieved later, as this directory and files are not used by the malware or displayed to the victim.\r\nAssociation With PlugX Malware\r\nIn addition to USB infection, both x32bridge.dat and the second PlugX malware variant discovered in VirusTotal check the target for specific running processes. If found, it terminates them and deletes the directories from which they were executed.\r\n\r\nX32bridge.dat seeks out process names starting with AAM and, if found, terminates the process and deletes specific directories associated with the process. The Sophos blog speculated that this behavior likely removed older PlugX malware variants. Previous variants attributed to PlugX started with AAM file names (i.e., AAM Updates.exe).\r\n\r\nThe second variant we discovered in VirusTotal also performs this check, including one for the specific process file name AAM Updates.exe. Additionally, if AAM Updates.exe is found, it deletes the directory AAM UpdatesikB, which is a folder that has also been associated with the PlugX malware family.\r\n\r\nSince both x32bridge.dat and the second PlugX malware variant discovered in VirusTotal share the same USB infection method along with other runtime behaviors, we can conclusively state that it is indeed associated with PlugX.\r\nConclusion\r\nPlugX malware has been used for over a decade and was historically extensively associated with Chinese nation-state APT groups. Over the years, it has been adopted and used by other threat groups, from nation-states to ransomware actors.\r\n\r\nThe typical tradecraft of PlugX uses benign files to achieve code execution, also known as DLL side loading, that many security vendors now detect and prevent. This might be part of why the actors added the capability to infect any attached removable media USB devices such as floppy, thumb or flash drives as well as any additional systems the USB is later plugged into.\r\n\r\nAny host infected with this variant of the PlugX malware will continuously monitor for new USB removable devices to infect. This PlugX malware also hides attacker files in a USB device with a novel technique, which makes the malicious files only viewable on a *nix OS or by mounting the USB device in a forensic tool. Because of this ability to evade detection, the PlugX malware can continue to spread and potentially jump to air-gapped networks.\r\n\r\nAdditionally, we discovered a similar variant of PlugX in VirusTotal with the added capability of copying all Adobe PDF and Microsoft Word documents from the infected host to the USB device's hidden folder created by the PlugX malware. The discovery of these samples indicates PlugX development is still alive and well among at least some technically skilled attackers, and it remains an active threat.\r\n\r\nFor Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this campaign:\r\n\r\n \tCortex XDR customers receive protection at the endpoints from the malware techniques described in this blog.\r\n \tWildFire cloud-based threat analysis service accurately identifies the malware described in this blog as malicious.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nUnit 42 Managed Threat Hunting Queries\r\n\/\/ Detecting potential DLL side loading \r\n\r\nconfig case_sensitive = false timeframe = 30d\r\n| dataset = xdr_data \r\n| filter event_type = ENUM.LOAD_IMAGE and action_module_signature_status = 3 and ((action_module_path contains \"mpsvc.dll\" and actor_process_image_name = \"aug.exe\") or (action_module_path contains \"dismcore.dll\" and actor_process_image_name = \"aug.exe\" ) or (action_module_path contains \"\\hex.dll\" and actor_process_image_name = \"SafeGuard.exe\") or (action_module_path contains \"x32bridge.dll\" and actor_process_image_name = \"x32dbg.exe\") or (action_module_path contains \"x32bridge.dll\" and actor_process_image_name = \"Mediae.exe\"))\r\n| comp count() as counter by actor_process_image_path , action_module_path , action_module_sha256 \r\n\r\n\/\/ Adding registry persistence \r\n\r\nconfig case_sensitive = false timeframe = 30d\r\n| dataset = xdr_data \r\n| filter event_type = ENUM.REGISTRY and event_sub_type = ENUM.REGISTRY_SET_VALUE and action_registry_key_name contains \"Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run\" and (action_registry_data contains \"x32dbg.exe\" or action_registry_data contains \"aug.exe\" or action_registry_data contains \"SafeGuard.exe\")\r\n| fields action_registry_data , action_registry_file_path , action_registry_key_name , actor_process_command_line , agent_hostname\r\n\/\/ Payload execution with rundll32.exe\r\n\r\nconfig case_sensitive = false timeframe = 30d\r\n| dataset = xdr_data\r\n| filter event_type = ENUM.PROCESS and action_process_image_path contains \"rundll32\" and (action_process_image_command_line contains \"\\akm.dat\" or action_process_image_command_line contains \"\\precious.dat\")\r\n| fields action_process_image_command_line , actor_process_image_command_line , agent_hostname\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nKnown PlugX Samples:\r\n8ec37dac2beaa494dcefec62f0bf4ae30a6ce44b27a588169d8f0476bbc94115\r\ne72e49dc1d95efabc2c12c46df373173f2e20dab715caf58b1be9ca41ec0e172\r\n0e9071714a4af0be1f96cffc3b0e58520b827d9e58297cb0e02d97551eca3799\r\n39280139735145ba6f0918b684ab664a3de7f93b1e3ebcdd071a5300486b8d20\r\n41a0407371124bcad7cab56227078ccd635ba6e6b4374b973754af96b7f58119\r\n02aa5b52137410de7cc26747f26e07b65c936d019ee2e1afae268a00e78a1f7f\r\n2a07877cb53404888e1b6f81bb07a35bc804daa1439317bccde9c498a521644c\r\n5d98d1193fcbb2479668a24697023829fc9dc1f7d31833c3c42b8380ef859ff1\r\nKnown File Directories\r\nC:\\ProgramData\\UsersDate\\Windows_NT\\Windows\\user\\Desktop\\\r\nC:\\Users\\Public\\Public Mediae\\\r\n&lt;usb volume&gt;:\\u00A0\\u00A0\\RECYCLER.BIN\\files\r\n&lt;usb volume&gt;:\\u00A0\\u00A0\\RECYCLER.BIN\\files\\da520e5\r\nKnown Windows Mutex Names\r\nLKU_Test_0.1\r\nLKU_Test_0.2\r\nTCP_0.1\r\nKnown PlugX Encrypted Payload File Names\r\nakm.dat\r\nprecious.dat\r\nx32bridge.dat\r\nGroza_1.dat\r\nKnown Windows Scheduled Task Names\r\nLKUFORYOU_1\r\nPRECIOUS_0.1\r\nKnown Windows Process Names (Observed Abused Benign Files)\r\nx32dbg.exe\r\nx32dbge.exe\r\nMediae.exe\r\nAug.exe\r\nPrecious.exe\r\nSafeGuard.exe\r\nDism.exe\r\nMITRE ATT&amp;CK Techniques\r\nATOM PlugX Malware\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tTHOR: <link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" />
<meta name="msapplication-TileImage" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" />
<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/plugx-variants-in-usbs/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=66c883b287" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/plugx-variants-in-usbs/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=66c883b287" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>
                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="#" class="copy-url" id="copyUrl" data-url="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/plugx-variants-in-usbs/" role="link" title="Copy link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:link"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-share-link.svg" alt="Link Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="mailto:?subject=Chinese%20PlugX%20Malware%20Hidden%20in%20Your%20USB%20Devices?&#038;body=Check%20out%20this%20article%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fplugx-variants-in-usbs%2F" role="link" title="Share in email" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:email"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-sms.svg" alt="Link Email"></a>

				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fplugx-variants-in-usbs%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fplugx-variants-in-usbs%2F&#038;title=Chinese%20PlugX%20Malware%20Hidden%20in%20Your%20USB%20Devices?" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>

				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fplugx-variants-in-usbs%2F&#038;text=Chinese%20PlugX%20Malware%20Hidden%20in%20Your%20USB%20Devices?" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fplugx-variants-in-usbs%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Chinese%20PlugX%20Malware%20Hidden%20in%20Your%20USB%20Devices?%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fplugx-variants-in-usbs%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="plugx-variants-in-usbs:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/plugx-variants-in-usbs/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-126789-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Recently, our Unit 42 incident response team was engaged in a Black Basta breach response that uncovered several tools and malware samples on the victim's machines, including <a href="https://www.cyber.nj.gov/alerts-advisories/gootloader-malware-platform-uses-sophisticated-techniques-to-deliver-malware" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GootLoader </a>malware, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/brute-ratel-c4-tool/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Brute Ratel C4</a> red-teaming tool and an older <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/thor-plugx-variant/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PlugX </a>malware sample. The PlugX malware stood out to us as this variant infects any attached removable USB media devices such as floppy, thumb or flash drives and any additional systems the USB is later plugged into.</p>
<p>This PlugX malware also hides actor files in a USB device using a novel technique that works even on the most recent Windows operating systems (OS) at the time of writing this post. This means the malicious files can only be viewed on a Unix-like (*nix) OS or by mounting the USB device in a forensic tool.</p>
<p>We also discovered a similar variant of PlugX in VirusTotal that infects USB devices and copies all Adobe PDF and Microsoft Word files from the host. It places these copies in a hidden folder on the USB device that is created by the malware.</p>
<p>PlugX is a second-stage implant used not only by multiple groups with a Chinese nexus but also by several cybercrime groups. It has been around for over a decade and has been observed in some high-profile cyberattacks, including the <a href="https://www.wired.com/2016/10/inside-cyberattack-shocked-us-government/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">U.S. Government Office of Personnel Management (OPM)</a> breach in 2015. It is a modular malware framework, supporting an evolving set of capabilities throughout the years.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against the types of threats discussed in this blog by products including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire">WildFire</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100.853%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 34.9464%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100.69%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/thor-plugx-variant/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">PlugX</span></a><b>,</b> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/brute-ratel-c4-tool/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Brute Ratel C4</span></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_ykx2wua3t4ir"></a>Introduction</h2>
<p>It's not uncommon for multiple malware samples to be discovered during an investigation, as occurred in this situation with GootLoader, Brute Ratel C4 and PlugX. Numerous threat actors compromise targets and can coexist simultaneously on the affected machine.</p>
<p>Because we can’t conclusively say whether these malware samples were left by one group or several, we can't attribute these tools to the Black Basta ransomware group. However, the version of Brute Ratel C4 used in this case is the same one reported by <a href="https://www.trendmicro.com/en_ca/research/22/j/black-basta-infiltrates-networks-via-qakbot-brute-ratel-and-coba.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trend Micro</a>, which also involved the Black Basta ransomware group.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_rux1bvc78w4n"></a>PlugX Malware Infection</h2>
<p>Historically, a PlugX infection begins by hijacking a known and trusted, digitally signed software application to load an actor-created encrypted payload. This technique has been used since 2010 and is listed in the MITRE ATT&amp;CK techniques as <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/002/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hijack execution flow DLL-Side loading</a> <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ID: T1574.002 Sub-technique T1574.</span></p>
<p>In this case, the threat actors decided to hijack a popular and free open source debugging tool for Windows called <a href="https://x64dbg.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">x64dbg</a>, which is used by the malware analysis/reverse engineering community. X64dbg applications are digitally signed by "Open Source Developer Duncan Ogilvie."</p>
<p>The developers of this tool offer two types of debugger applications: x64 for 64-bit applications and x32 for 32-bit applications. In this case, the actors used <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32dbg.exe</span>, which is the 32-bit debugger of <span style="font-family: georgia, palatino, serif;">x64dbg</span>.</p>
<p>Upon execution of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32dbg.exe</span>, Microsoft Windows will attempt to resolve any dependency files necessary to run the application. That search starts locally (i.e., in the current working directory). If found, the necessary files are loaded and executed.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">X32bridge.dll</span> is a Windows Dynamic Link Library (DLL) dependency file of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32dbg.exe</span>. A legitimate <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dll</span> also carries the same digital signature. In this case, the file is not signed.</p>
<p>Once loaded, the malware searches locally for an actor-created encrypted payload file: x32bridge.dat (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e72e49dc1d95efabc2c12c46df373173f2e20dab715caf58b1be9ca41ec0e172</span>).</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">X32bridge.dat</span> was first submitted to VirusTotal on Jan. 22, 2021. As of Dec. 15, 2022, it has a detection score of eight out of 61 engines. None of the engines identify the file as PlugX malware.</p>
<p>Once loaded and decrypted in memory, the malware infects the host and any removable USB devices attached with the PlugX malware. Figure 1 below illustrates PlugX DLL side loading using x64dbg DLL hijacking.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126790" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126790" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126790 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-1.png" alt="Image 1 is a diagram of the process whereby the PlugX DLL sideloading. " width="900" height="455" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126790" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. PlugX DLL sideloading using x64dbg.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Both the hijacking of x64dbg and the association of this behavior with the PlugX malware were reported by Sophos back in <a href="https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/11/04/a-new-apt-uses-dll-side-loads-to-killlsomeone/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">November 2020</a>. Their blog refers to this malware as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>KilllSomeOne</em></span>, based on a Program Database (PDB) string found in one of the binaries.</p>
<p>Sophos performed an excellent analysis of the samples and touched on the USB infection. We confirmed that our sample matched the behaviors described in their report. From there, we wanted to expand our research by focusing on the USB infection, other USB variants in the wild and links to the PlugX malware.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_mzn6u9xbft8"></a>PlugX Malware USB Overview</h2>
<p>The technique used by the PlugX malware to hide files in a USB device involves using a certain Unicode character. This hinders Windows Explorer and the command shell (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe</span>) from displaying the USB directory structure and any files, concealing them from the victim.</p>
<p>The Unicode character used by this PlugX malware for the directories is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">00A0</span> (a whitespace character called a no-break space). The whitespace character prevents the Windows Operating System from rendering the directory name, concealing it rather than leaving a nameless folder in Explorer.</p>
<p>To achieve code execution of the malware from the hidden directory, a Windows shortcut (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span>) file is created on the root folder of the USB device. The shortcut path to the malware contains the Unicode whitespace character, which is a space that does not cause a line break, but this is not visible when viewed via Windows Explorer, as shown below in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126792" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126792" style="width: 678px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126792 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-2.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of Windows Explorer, showing the Shortcut tab in the USB drive properties (named TESTDRIVE). It lists the target type, location and Target, where the target shows the hidden directory with extended ASCII characters. " width="678" height="416" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126792" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Windows shortcut properties for accessing the hidden directory.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When the shortcut file is viewed in a hex editor, the hex representation of these characters is shown as highlighted below in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126794" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126794" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126794 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-3.png" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of a hex editor where the extended ASCII characters are highlighted. There are two, and both are “A0”." width="900" height="158" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126794" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Windows shortcut properties shown in a hex editor display.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The PlugX malware uses the Component Object Model (COM) interface to create the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> files and includes the Unicode character <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">00A0</span>. It does this by creating an instance of a shell desktop to create the associated Windows shortcut files. The ShellLink <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SetArguments</span> method is used to set the command line arguments, which include the white space no break Unicode character, as shown in Figure 4 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126796" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126796" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126796 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-4.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of the COM ShellLink command line arguments. " width="900" height="185" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126796" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. COM <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ShellLink::SetArguments</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Finally, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>ShellLink::Save</em></span> method saves the shortcut file with all the changes.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_90jm739ksup9"></a>PlugX Malware USB Infection</h2>
<p>The PlugX malware <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dll</span> loads <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dat</span>, which is responsible for implanting the host with malware and infecting any attached removable media USB devices such as floppy, thumb or flash drives. If a removable media device is found, the following steps are performed:</p>
<ol>
<li>It creates the following directory structure:<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>&lt;usb volume&gt;</em>:\u00A0\u00A0\RECYCLER.BIN\files</span>. Example: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><em>F:\ \ \RECYCLER.BIN\files</em></span>.</li>
<li>It creates a hidden file named desktop.ini in each folder, which specifies the icon for the folder. This file contains the following data:</li>
</ol>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[.ShellClassInfo]<br />
</span><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">IconResource=%systemroot%\system32\SHELL32.dll,7</span></p>
<p>The Windows OS uses a single file to retrieve icon images that are displayed on the desktop as shortcuts or from Windows Explorer files and folders. The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Shell32.dll</span> file contains a list of icons and a unique number. In this case, the drive icon and the number 7 are used, as shown below in Figure 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126798" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126798" style="width: 150px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126798 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-5.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of the drive icon, showing a drive with a green light against a blue background. The number 7 is at the bottom." width="150" height="162" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126798" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Drive icon number 7.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The use of this drive icon makes the directories appear as drives within Windows Explorer when viewed with hidden files enabled. If deleted, the directories appear as folders.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>In the second directory, it creates a subfolder named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECYLER.BIN</span>. This directory acts as a recycle bin. In that directory is a subdirectory named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">files</span> and a hidden <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">desktop.ini</span> file. This <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">desktop.ini</span> file contains the following data:</li>
</ol>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">[.ShellClassInfo]</span></p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CLSID = {645FF040-5081-101B-9F08-00AA002F954E}</span></p>
<p>This CLSID instructs Windows Explorer to display the created <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECYCLER.BIN</span> folder as a recycle bin directory by giving it the recycle bin icon. This is shown in Figure 11 as an example.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">files</span> subfolder contains copies of the PlugX malware <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32dbg.exe</span>, any encrypted actor <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.dat</span> files and the actor’s malicious DLL. An example of this is shown in Figure 6 below.</li>
</ol>
<figure id="attachment_126800" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126800" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126800 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-6.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of the program WinHex displaying the name, extensions, size, created date, bodied date, accessed date, attribution, and sector number in the files subfolder. " width="900" height="165" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126800" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Infected UBS removable device displayed via WinHex.</figcaption></figure>
<p>It should be noted that pre-infection of the USB device, existing files or directories on the root of the removable device are moved to the second hidden folder on the USB device, as shown below in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126802" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126802" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126802 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-7.png" alt="Image 7 is a side-by-side root directory comparison of a non-infected (left) versus an infected (right) USB device. " width="900" height="296" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126802" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Side-by-side comparison of the root directories of a non-infected versus infected USB device.</figcaption></figure>
<ol start="5">
<li>Whenever the shortcut file from the infected USB device is clicked, the PlugX malware launches Windows Explorer and passes the directory path as a parameter. This then displays the files on the USB device from within the hidden directories and also infects the host with the PlugX malware. The victim sees their files and assumes all is working as expected.</li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 8 below illustrates how an infected USB thumb drive would appear to a victim in Windows Explorer using default settings (i.e., not displaying hidden files).</p>
<figure id="attachment_126804" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126804" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126804 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-8.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of Windows Explorer showing the infected USB drive. Show hidden files is not enabled in this instance. " width="900" height="435" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126804" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device. (Show hidden files not enabled.)</figcaption></figure>
<p>An infected PlugX USB device has no files or directories in the root folder and contains only a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.lnk</span> file.</p>
<p>Figure 9 shows that the shortcut file is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">TESTDRIVE</span>, which matches the USB device name. The shortcut file is responsible for infecting the host and navigating to the hidden directory on the USB device each time it is clicked. For example, the shortcut file referenced in Figure 9 contains the following data:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%comspec% /q /c " \ \RECYCLER.BIN\files\x32dbg.exe"</span></p>
<p>Once the target clicks the shortcut, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32dbg.exe</span> is launched via <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe</span> from the hidden files directory on the USB device. The host the USB is attached to is now infected with the PlugX malware.</p>
<p>When viewing the contents of the infected USB device with Windows Explorer and hidden items enabled, a victim would see the following images:</p>
<figure id="attachment_126806" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126806" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126806 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-9.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of Windows Explorer showing the root folder of the USB drive. " width="900" height="84" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126806" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device (root folder).</figcaption></figure>
<p>They would then see the following, as shown in Figure 10, within the first hidden directory:</p>
<figure id="attachment_126808" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126808" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126808 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-10.png" alt="Image 10 is a screenshot of Windows Explorer showing the root folder of the infected USB drive, displaying the first hidden directory." width="900" height="90" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126808" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Windows Explorer showing an infected USB removable device (hidden directory number one).</figcaption></figure>
<p>As shown in Figure 11, Windows Explorer displays another hidden directory along with a shortcut file. The shortcut file has the same properties to launch <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32dbg.exe</span> and will infect the host with the USB device attached.</p>
<p>When viewing the contents of the next hidden folder, Windows Explorer shows the following directory structure:</p>
<figure id="attachment_126810" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126810" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126810 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-11.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of Windows Explorer showing the root folder of the infected USB drive, displaying the second hidden directory with a folder disguised as a recycling bin." width="900" height="123" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126810" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device (hidden directory number two).</figcaption></figure>
<p>This directory contains a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECYLER.BIN</span> folder that masquerades as a Windows recycle bin, along with any files or directories that existed in the root folder of the USB device at the time of infection. When viewing the contents of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECYLER.BIN</span> with Windows Explorer, a victim will see what’s shown in Figure 12:</p>
<figure id="attachment_126812" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126812" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126812 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-12.png" alt="Image 12 is a screenshot of Windows Explorer showing the contents of the RECYCLER.BIN folder. There are hidden malware files that cannot be detected outside of the use of specialized tools." width="900" height="149" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126812" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Windows Explorer showing infected USB Removable Device (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECYLER.BIN</span> folder).</figcaption></figure>
<p>Since the default setting for Windows Explorer is not to show hidden items, the only item visible to the victim is the shortcut file, as shown in Figure 8. Even with hidden files enabled, Windows Explorer or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe</span> cannot show the malware files that reside in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">files</span> subdirectory.</p>
<p>The malware files can only be viewed on a *nix OS or by mounting the USB device in a forensic tool. Figure 13 shows how the USB device looks once it’s mounted in Ubuntu, browsing to it via File Explorer.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126814" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126814" style="width: 549px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126814 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-13.png" alt="Image 13 is a screenshot of how the USB drive looks while browsing its contents in Ubuntu’s File Explorer." width="549" height="141" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126814" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Ubuntu File Explorer viewing an infected USB device.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_my2f3ke6g00"></a>PlugX Malware Post USB Infection</h2>
<p>When a host is infected with this variant of the PlugX malware, the malware continuously monitors for USB removable devices. Once a USB device is discovered and infected, any new files written to the USB device root folder post-infection are moved to the hidden folder within the USB device. Since the Windows shortcut file resembles that of a USB device and the malware displays the victim's files, they unwittingly continue to spread the PlugX malware.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_kxfkqtej5zha"></a>PlugX Malware USB Variant Two</h2>
<p>Armed with this knowledge, we wondered if other similar PlugX USB infection malware existed in the wild. File SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5b496972a86cea66aeecaac6e3f67a92e22f35cd5d2a98d54a2f1218fcd5dfc5</span> in VirusTotal matches the behaviors of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dat</span>, specifically the creation of the Windows Scheduled Task and PDB string referenced in the Sophos blog.</p>
<p>This file is a Windows x86 PE file (DLL), the in-memory equivalent of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dat</span>. Our analysis shows the runtime behavior is identical to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dat</span> USB infection detailed earlier, but it has an added capability. It copies documents from the host machine to a new hidden USB subfolder named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">da520e5</span>.</p>
<p>The malware specifically copies all Adobe PDF and Microsoft Word documents from the host to this directory. Figure 14 below shows an example of the directory and files copied from our host.</p>
<figure id="attachment_126816" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-126816" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-126816 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/word-image-126789-14.png" alt="Image 14 is a screenshot of Drive F displaying the PlugX malware variant with two exfil files. It shows their names, extensions, size, creation and modification dates, access dates, attribution, and sector. " width="900" height="115" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-126816" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. PlugX malware variant with two exfil files.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This PlugX USB malware variant was designed to exfiltrate specific files from its target that could be retrieved later, as this directory and files are not used by the malware or displayed to the victim.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_y43g3soh33bh"></a>Association With PlugX Malware</h2>
<p>In addition to USB infection, both <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dat</span> and the second PlugX malware variant discovered in VirusTotal check the target for specific running processes. If found, it terminates them and deletes the directories from which they were executed.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">X32bridge.dat</span> seeks out process names starting with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AAM</span> and, if found, terminates the process and deletes specific directories associated with the process. The Sophos blog speculated that this behavior likely removed older PlugX malware variants. Previous variants attributed to PlugX started with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AAM</span> file names (i.e., <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AAM Updates.exe</span>).</p>
<p>The second variant we discovered in VirusTotal also performs this check, including one for the specific process file name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AAM Updates.exe</span>. Additionally, if <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AAM Updates.exe</span> is found, it deletes the directory <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AAM UpdatesikB</span>, which is a folder that has also been associated with the PlugX malware family.</p>
<p>Since both <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x32bridge.dat</span> and the second PlugX malware variant discovered in VirusTotal share the same USB infection method along with other runtime behaviors, we can conclusively state that it is indeed associated with PlugX.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_rdgacrismcfz"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>PlugX malware has been used for over a decade and was historically extensively associated with Chinese nation-state APT groups. Over the years, it has been adopted and used by other threat groups, from nation-states to ransomware actors.</p>
<p>The typical tradecraft of PlugX uses benign files to achieve code execution, also known as DLL side loading, that many security vendors now detect and prevent. This might be part of why the actors added the capability to infect any attached removable media USB devices such as floppy, thumb or flash drives as well as any additional systems the USB is later plugged into.</p>
<p>Any host infected with this variant of the PlugX malware will continuously monitor for new USB removable devices to infect. This PlugX malware also hides attacker files in a USB device with a novel technique, which makes the malicious files only viewable on a *nix OS or by mounting the USB device in a forensic tool. Because of this ability to evade detection, the PlugX malware can continue to spread and potentially jump to air-gapped networks.</p>
<p>Additionally, we discovered a similar variant of PlugX in VirusTotal with the added capability of copying all Adobe PDF and Microsoft Word documents from the infected host to the USB device's hidden folder created by the PlugX malware. The discovery of these samples indicates PlugX development is still alive and well among at least some technically skilled attackers, and it remains an active threat.</p>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this campaign:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> customers receive protection at the endpoints from the malware techniques described in this blog.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> cloud-based threat analysis service accurately identifies the malware described in this blog as malicious.</li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the</span><a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Unit 42 Incident Response team</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> or call:</span></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">APAC: +65.6983.8730</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://cyberthreatalliance.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-126789-_x0edrufqll1g"></a>Unit 42 Managed Threat Hunting Queries</h2>
<p></p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-6762321581ac3972674165" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
// Detecting potential DLL side loading 

config case_sensitive = false timeframe = 30d
| dataset = xdr_data 
| filter event_type = ENUM.LOAD_IMAGE and action_module_signature_status = 3 and ((action_module_path contains "mpsvc.dll" and actor_process_image_name = "aug.exe") or (action_module_path contains "dismcore.dll" and actor_process_image_name = "aug.exe" ) or (action_module_path contains "\hex.dll" and actor_process_image_name = "SafeGuard.exe") or (action_module_path contains "x32bridge.dll" and actor_process_image_name = "x32dbg.exe") or (action_module_path contains "x32bridge.dll" and actor_process_image_name = "Mediae.exe"))
| comp count() as counter by actor_process_image_path , action_module_path , action_module_sha256 </textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">

				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-e">action_module_path </span><span class="crayon-i">contains</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"\hex.dll"</span><span </span><span class="crayon-s">"SafeGuard.exe"</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">or</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">and</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">actor_process_image_name</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"x32dbg.exe"</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">or</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">and</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">actor_process_image_name</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h">
